dt: {bc}to establish the existence, truth, or validity of (as by evidence or logic)

dt.t: the charges were never {it}proved{/it} in court

dt: {bc}to demonstrate as having a particular quality or worth

dt.t: the vaccine has been {it}proven{/it} effective after years of tests

dt: {bc}to show (oneself) to be worthy or capable

dt.t: eager to {wi}prove{/wi} myself in the new job

dt: {bc}to test the truth, validity, or genuineness of
{bc}to test the worth or quality of
{bc}to check the correctness of (something, such as an arithmetic result)
{bc}to learn or find out by experience
{bc}to turn out especially after trial or test

pt: The past participle {it}proven{/it}, originally the past participle of {it}preve{/it}, a Middle English variant of {it}prove{/it} that survived in Scotland, has gradually worked its way into standard English over the past three and a half centuries. It seems to have first become established in legal use and to have come only slowly into literary use. Tennyson was one of its earliest frequent users, probably for metrical reasons. It was disapproved by 19th century grammarians, one of whom included it in a list of "words that are not words." Surveys made some 50 or 60 years ago indicated that {it}proved{/it} was about four times as frequent as {it}proven.{/it} But our evidence from the last 30 or 35 years shows this no longer to be the case. As a past participle {it}proven{/it} is now about as frequent as {it}proved{/it} in all contexts. As an attributive adjective

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}prover, pruver{/it}, from Latin {it}probare{/it} to test, prove, from {it}probus{/it} good, honest, from {it}pro-{/it} for, in favor + {it}-bus{/it} (akin to Old English {it}bēon{/it} to be) {ma}{mat|pro-|}, {mat|be|}{/ma}
shortdef: to establish the existence, truth, or validity of (as by evidence or logic)
to demonstrate as having a particular quality or worth
to show (oneself) to be worthy or capable

dt: {bc}to turn out to be satisfactory or as expected

shortdef: to turn out to be satisfactory or as expected

dt: {bc}to show that one is right about something

dt.t: He's willing to do almost anything to {it}prove a point{/it}.

shortdef: to show that one is right about something

dt: {bc}to show that one is able to do something or to succeed

dt.t: She was eager to {it}prove herself{/it} in her new job.
She has {it}proven herself{/it} (to be) capable of excellent work.

shortdef: to show that one is able to do something or to succeed

dt: {bc}to prove that one is a strong or brave man

dt.t: Boxing was a way for him to {it}prove his manhood{/it}.

shortdef: to prove that one is a strong or brave man

dt.t: He {it}proved his mettle{/it} as a fighter tonight.

shortdef: to prove how tough one is

dt: {bc}to be eventually found to be helpful

dt.t: The data could {it}prove (to be) useful{/it} in identifying future problems.

shortdef: to be eventually found to be helpful

stems: have got nothing left to prove

dt: {bc}to not have to do anything more to show that one is skillful, successful, etc.

dt.t: I've accomplished everything I wanted to; I{it}'ve got nothing left to prove{/it}.

shortdef: to not have to do anything more to show that one is skillful, successful, etc.

meta.id: what are you trying to prove
stems: what are you trying to prove

hwi.hw: what are you trying to prove

dt: used to ask why someone is behaving in a way that seems unreasonable

dt.t: {it}What are you trying to prove{/it} by behaving so recklessly?

shortdef: —used to ask why someone is behaving in a way that seems unreasonable

dt.t: Her success {it}goes to show{/it} that if you work hard, you can make your dreams come true.

shortdef: to help show or prove something
